They were laughing at people trying to get through, including airline crew and airport staff for being frustrated. This causes anger and frustration and a poor overall mood for passengers when good and positive attitudes would support happy and positive travelers and less issues on airplanes. Embarrassed for this country with international travelers when other countries are kind and calm to travelers because they know it is important for commerce, mental health, and relations with other people. When we finally made it through there were 15 TSA staff standing just inside the concourse having a meeting. Gate staff were kind as well as the staff at the Juan Valdez coffee shop, otherwise would have given a zero.

reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  Such a messy place. It’s a very crowded place with not enough staff. Due to air traffic my flight got delayed from the departure city. Many of us having a connection flight and there were only a few agents working so because of this a lot of us were late for the connection flight. After this the check point took even longer to get through and once again not enough staff was there working. Also I had to pick up my luggage and drop it for the connection flight something I never had to do with any other airline. We traveled with American Airlines (not recommended) after getting through all of this we had to walk miles again to get to our gate which was at the very end of the hallway only to let us know that we had lost our flight and there was nothing to do other than placing us at a standby list and hope for the best only because it wasn’t the airline fault. According to the American airlines agent this had to do with the controllers and the air traffic so they wouldn’t offer us a hotel room or food just because this was the airport fault. We ended up spending a whole night there where we couldn’t even get a bag of chips because they got rid of vending machines so they have no food options passed 11 pm. Honestly a pretty bad experience. I’ve been to plenty of airports and they’re never this disorganized. Miami you need to step up!

author: James Dunne
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  If you're a fan of inefficiency and a dash of the cold shoulder,  venturing into MIA is like stepping into a time machine, and not the cool, futuristic kind. It's more akin to a leap backwards into an era where charm and functionality are myths, and cramped, outdated spaces are the harsh reality.  The staff ability to maintain an aura of indifference in the face of any question or plea for help is truly commendable. It's as if they've taken the concept of 'the cold shoulder' and elevated it to an art form. Navigating the airport is akin to participating in an escape room you never signed up for. The layout is so cramped and convoluted. It’s clear the design was inspired by a labyrinth, with a dash of "let's see how many people we can confuse before noon." Calling it 'old and dated' is a kindness. It's as if the airport is stuck in a bygone era, stubbornly refusing to join us in the 21st century. The charm of yesteryear has certainly overstayed its welcome here. But the pièce de résistance has to be the TSA security clearance - a spectacle so inefficient and embarrassing, it deserves its own reality TV show. The TSA staff, not wanting to be outdone by their airport colleagues, take rudeness to new heights, skirting the line of abusiveness with a finesse that would make a drill sergeant blush. It's a process so fraught with frustration, you'd think it was designed as a test of human endurance. In an era where digital connectivity is akin to oxygen, MIA somehow manages to turn free WiFi into a luxury item. Thanks to the generosity of American Express, passengers can access the internet, provided they have the patience to sit through ads. It's a charming reminder of the dial-up era, a nostalgic throwback that no one asked for. The concept of passenger experience seems to be an alien one at MIA. From the lack of food outlets to the scarcity of lounges, it's as if they're pioneering a new minimalist approach to airport amenities - less is more, and in the case of MIA, much less. In conclusion, if you're seeking an airport experience that combines the charm of a Soviet-era bus station with the efficiency of a sloth, look no further than Miami International Airport. It's an adventure you won't forget, no matter how hard you try. I wholeheartedly advise anyone to avoid this horrible, dingy, old, awful airport at all costs. It's truly a masterclass in how not to run an airport.

reviewBody: Not Verified |  My experience at this airport was terrible. I was connecting through Miami in a flight to Barcelona (Spain). The connection was quite short (90 mins) due to an earlier delay in the first flight. The lines for passport control were massive, I have never seen anything like it, so I asked the staff if there was a priority line for connections and emphasised my short connection. After a bit of confusion and me having done most of the regular line, eventually someone came and handed us the orange cards and we went into a separate queue. The short connection queue was still quite long, so I requested one of the staff if he could organise it prioritising those with flights leaving earliest, like my own. I was understandably quite nervous about missing my flight, as I was travelling with my mother, a senior with a disability. The gentleman said he couldn’t do anything and that I had to wait, I insisted that the system was making little sense but was in no way disrespectful. Another passenger was allowed to go to the front of the queue however, which I thought was unfair particularly to me as I was the one with the earliest flight. I also can’t understand as a key international hub there isn’t any organisation whatsoever to connecting flights

reviewBody: Not Verified | I was disappointed with Miami airport on my departure on Oct 11, 2023, and then became even more disappointed upon my arrival on Oct. 18. author: Clyde Haggard
reviewBody: Not Verified |  This is the most mismanaged airport that I have encountered in over 500,000 miles of travel.  Poor signage (DFW successfully redid all of their signs a few years ago). We were directed in the wrong direction several times. Asking employees for directions was no help because they did not know where baggage claim 6 was either.  Poor maintenance - Most elevators were out of service, and had apparently been so for months or years, since the signs directing you to the next working elevators were ragged and worn.  Restrooms not serviced - no paper towels or air dryers. Transportation services not available - the train was not operable; the golf carts were sitting unused with no driver. This was in Terminal D which is almost a mile long. When we arrived on an international flight we had an extremely long walk to customs and there were no chairs in which to rest.  There were unreasonably long distances to walk to immigration and customs - sometimes the signs sent domestic and international passengers in different directions, only for them to join again. The signs indicating which line to get in were confusing - we saw dozens of people being moved from one line to another.  It was very difficult to find hotel shuttles, and they are located in a dark area across several roads from the terminal. The electrical outlets in our seats had no power.  The entire design of the airport appeared to be by an architect who specializes in corn mazes.

reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | I was born and raised in Miami Dade County and so disappointed and embarrassed of our airport. Management needs a good management system. It's done at other airports in Florida, successfully. The whole airport looks like it has patchwork construction and design, archaic layout. Wheelchairs and transport buses running where people walk! Gate signs don't make sense. I had to ask people where to find everything. Loud speaker sometimes can't be heard, sometimes loud. Terrible!! Where is our tax payer money going. It's certainly not going to this place. Governor DeSantis needs to overhaul the management. Tampa has a beautiful airport, comfortable, organized and beautiful restrooms. Jacksonville too...What the heck is going on in Miami??

author: Darin Sanders
reviewBody: Not Verified |  I’m embarrassed for the U.S. that this airport is a “gateway” for so many people. My flight from Dallas Love Field arrived in the G Concourse which reminds me of the old New York LaGuardia terminal. Low ceilings, narrow walkways, dirty, dark, interior. I made my way to ground transportation which was a nightmare. The signage is confusing and with the proliferation of ride share apps like Uber, Lyft, etc., one would think there would be ample signage. The entire ground transportation area is confusing, with inadequate signage. Then, there are the airport staff. I had trouble getting a Lyft, and decided to take a cab. The cab driver told me that since I was going to Hilton Airport Blue Lagoon, I had to take a “blue” taxi. I asked an airport ground transportation worker for directions and he pointed and said, “at the end.” I never found the blue taxi and finally ended up waiting for my hotel’s courtesy van for another 30 minutes.  Upon arrival back to the airport for my departing flight, the same chaos ensued. I arrived at the airport at 8:00 a.m. for my 11:55 a.m. flight back to Dallas. Since I had time to spare, I went to the Star Alliance Lounge between H and J. Security checkpoint was horrible. Crowded, confusing, and I was in the line for the TSA Pre-Check which they were merging with the CLEAR and general security screening. Employees are brash, if not just downright rude. The walkway between H and J was much nicer; except for the restrooms. Wow - I think they imported these from old gas stations. Dark, dirty, in disrepair. I finally made my way to the Star Alliance Lounge. The entrance to the elevator from the concourse level is two double doors that made me think I was going into the back kitchen of an old diner. Followed, by a dirty elevator with taped signage directing me to the lounge. The walk from the elevator to the lounge entrance made me think I was in the wrong place, but I kept walking and eventually found it. Finally a nice escape from the worst airport I’ve ever experienced.

reviewBody: Not Verified | My recent experience connecting through MIA was absolutely atrocious. author: Taylor M Malone
reviewBody: Not Verified |  Surprised to say that this airport did not exceed expectations at all. Since stepping off the aircraft to bags being in baggage claim was roughly 45min-1 hour. Now I flew American Airlines, which actually never took my bag off the flight so my bags ended up being sent to Vegas. I know that the problem is more with American Airlines and not the airport, but when trying to get help on where to go and who to talk to I was met with great resistance. No one wanted to help and after spending over four hours trying to find where my bag was I eventually left and gave up. The workers in the airport were incompetent. I never once raised my voice or had an angry attitude towards a worker, because I know that it’s not their fault that my bags were lost. However, I waited in baggage claim line for 45min waiting to get an answer on where my bag was. When I got to the front, the associate refused to scan my baggage slip and told me to go look in a pile of bags I already looked through. After telling the associate I had already gone through all the bags with other associates she just waived her hand at me to leave. The airport layout is horrendous and it feels like a run down mall instead of an airport. Everything is dirty and the seat availability is absolutely slim. There is very little seating for people who have to wait for flights. Even on a day with little to no delays you find yourself either shoulder to shoulder with someone or sitting on the floor. On my departure trip back to the airport I arrived, come to find out instead of holding my bag they lost for me to recheck, they sent it on a flight back to Dallas after we had already discussed over the phone I would pick it up myself in Miami. I got to the airport at approximately 8:30am and my flight didn’t board until 3:00pm. Since I was coming from a cruise I didn’t have much option but to wait in the airport. Since I entered the terminal there was a loud alarm that stated “may we have your attention”, “the current alarm in being investigated by the fire department, please standby for more instructions.” This alarm continued to go off every minute even after I got on my flight to leave. I understand the safety of having alarms, but it sounded like it had been going off for days. Seating was again slim and the restrooms were absolutely disastrous. Overall, if you plan on spending anytime at all at an airport make sure it is not in Miami. For an international airport I am shocked at how horrendous the experience is. The service and associates around the airport treat people nothing more than a ticket. 1/10 I am never coming back to this airport, I would rather spend hundreds of more dollars than spend another minute here.

header: "chaos referred to as the Miami Airport"
author: Will Hempel
reviewBody: Not Verified |  There is no possible way to accurately describe the chaos referred to as the Miami Airport. If one is an international flier arriving at this airport, the chaos begins with trying to secure luggage. People running into each other in a tiny pedestrian lane occupied by persons entering and exiting the baggage area. No accurate signage for direction, just a few employees in yellow vests waving their arms. Next is the reloading of baggage prior to entering Immigration then TSA. Because of a recent knee replacement, I was relegated to the scanner line. Little movement of the line due to a break down of the ONE machine. We were directed to the metal detector whereby the agent just waved us through (the machine beeped, but was flag through anyway). Next was our quest to find Terminal E (gate 30). Signage was confusing. Nobody to direct. Found a flight attendant who directed us to a Skytrain, it could not adequately explain where to go next. A stroke of luck took us to the gate. We were in the last boarding group which was being called as we approached the gate. We have traveled to some second tiered countries that are better equipped to handle passengers in an organized manner. This is no way to run an airport. One that I will avoid at all costs.

reviewBody: Not Verified |  We left Cancun and had a layover in Miami. Despite having many booths to help folks, there was just four employees manning them, and all but one employee worked at a very slow pace. After spending an hour in the Customs line we then proceeded to get our luggage. No staff member explained that we needed to pick up our luggage and take it to another location. Once we figured out what needed to be done we then proceeded to security. Once we arrived there, the line was crazy long and it took over an hour to get through that line. The staff there also worked at a very slow pace. We spent over two and a half hours getting through security and customs which caused us to miss our connecting flight. There were many people in line with us who also complained about poor customer service, slow service, and lack of coordination by the staff. In fact, a lot of other people missed their connecting flights as a result of this disaster. I hope I never had to visit the Miami airport again.

reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  Return flight with BA to T5 Heathrow. Easy to find the BA check in desks, queues not too bad and after 15 minutes we went through Security. Found the American Airlines Flagship Lounge (near Gate D 30) and checked in with a glass of champagne. Sat doiwn to find that my wife had left her cell phone at security in one of the plastic trays. A half hour search back at the security gate, and with the help of security staff and a fellow passenger and thankfully she found it. Don't know whether this is a trend but we have found Miami International has improved over the years - far, far better than it was, say, 15 years ago. Would, on this basis, recommend.

author: G Baker
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | A very disorganized airport. Wait until you read this! We arrived from Madrid into their international terminal. We had a connecting flight to our final destination. reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified |  I’ve always preferred FLL when traveling to visit family in Colombia because of streamlined customs process, but last summer in MIA, everything was good. Initial customs was not bad but then everyone was screened again! Usually they spot check but today, there was one PO’d girl checking passports and only one screening lane open. A guy was walking back and forth saying to put tablets and computers separate and shoes and belts off. The crowd was getting impatient when some young group cut the line. A supervisor was called out and they were sent back after some yelling and shouting. Finally another lane opened right as we were up front. Then as we were taking shoes and belts off the agent said “why are you pulling your computers out?” I had the regrettable audacity to inform him the the other agent was shouting those instructions to the crowd. That annoyed him so we stuffed the laptop and tablet back into their case and moved on to baggage claim and re-check.so why don’t they screen all bags again if all people are being scanned again after being in a contained environment? This was bizarre and chaotic at the very least and unprofessional at worst. Unless my life depends on it I will avoid MIA for the 2 years I have left before moving to Colombia.

reviewBody: Not Verified |  I'm glad I finally used Miami as my re-entry port on a return from Jamaica. It taught me a valuable lesson. So back we went to the main corridor, where we saw directional arrows for Gates D-E etc, so down that corridor we race, looking for an American Rebooking desk. None in sight, anywhere, despite this being a major American hub. Stopped at one gate that was staffed and asked where the rebooking desk was, and was told it was something like D-37 or D-3, and then the agent volunteered that one might be a little closer, so off in that direction we ran. When we finally got there, we were told that the doors had already been closed (never mind that it would have been about a 15 minute walk to get there anyway). So we resigned ourselves to an interminable wait down near D-1, where a bottled beer was "only" $10.50, not counting tax and a "suggested tip of $1.50." When it finally was near time for the departure for the later flight, suddenly there was a flurry of activity at the adjacent gates, when apparently four American flights were to depart within 15 minutes of one another from gates D-1 to D-5. And since there seemed to be only one PA, the assembled passengers became understandably restless when the gate attendant announced "we are now boarding Groups 1 and 2" without bothering to state the destination or flight number. Confusing? You bet. Especially when said announcement was drowned out by another PA telling "passenger XXX, please report to the gate." Final boarding began when five wheelchairs were rolled to the plane, followed very quickly by anyone who simply showed his/her boarding pass and walked aboard. There was only one American gate agent on duty, apparently all the others were still dealing with the adjacent flights. Not professional at all.

author: N Thomas
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | I had a connection in Miami last week, and not a lot of time before landing from Spain and needing to transfer, so I was in a rush to get to my connecting gate. I used mobile pass and went through and asked the person which queue to get into, and she said 35 or 36. I went to 36, and the officer at the desk said I was in the wrong line. I asked him which line was the correct one and pointed at the woman behind us (she was maybe 10 feet behind me) and said "she told me to go to this line" and he just waived randomly to the other 35 lines and said "back there". He did not even bother looking up from his cell phone. So, I went back to the woman who had told me originally that it was line 35 or 36, and she said, "oh, I meant 34 or 35." (We were standing right in front of lines 34, 35, and 36.) She seriously could not have been less concerned that she's giving out misinformation. The officer in line 36 also could not be bothered to simply say the queue right next to him was the correct one. Seriously. They are useless, and do not even attempt to improve. They should all be fired for their attitudes and giving out incorrect information. This is not the first time I've had a terrible experience flying through Miami and I avoid it whenever possible.

header: "disgusted with the level of nastiness and ignorance"
author: S Alt
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | Absolutely disgusted with the level of nastiness and ignorance by the employees. Our tickets told us to go to terminal H. Once we passed security and went to our gate we were told it had changed to G. The security at G wouldn't let us pass because the tickets said terminal H. It took us forever to persuade them that the flight terminal and gate were changed. At this point my mother-in-law couldn't walk anymore because we were standing in line forever and she is elderly and has diabetes. When we asked for help several employees sneered and were sarcastic asking if they should roll out the red carpet for us. It was just the two of us and 4 kids. My daughter had dropped hot water on her chest just an hour before and was treated by first responders (who were absolutely amazing) at the Military Lounge, so I couldn't help her, my mother-in-law, and the other 3 kids all at the same time. Because my MIL could barely walk we were talking to each other that chances are we'd miss our flight, at which point one of the TSA agents started yelling how she didn't care and sat for over 10 mins without letting me have my shoes or my daughter's ice pouch the first responders gave us. They absolutely refused to let us keep the aloe we were given by the medics because I refused to show them my daughter's burned chest! She is 7! She was already distressed because of the second degree burns. She had huge blisters on her belly and chest that were treated by the medics and bandaged. Where is your humanity? Is your life so miserable you need to take it out on a little girl who sat in pain for 4 hours because you couldn't let her have her medicine? How dare you ask to see my daughter's bare chest to confirm she has burns? It's called HIPAA for a reason. You are not a medical professional. Is your day better because you managed to put down a military spouse, her four children and her mother-in-law? I cannot believe these are the people my husband serves and protects.

header: "hardly words to describe how abysmal this airport is"
author: Fernando Armstrong-Fumero
reviewBody: Not Verified |  There are hardly words to describe how abysmal this airport is. I had 2 hours to make a connection from Mexico City to Hartford. American Airlines should have known better than to book such a short layover through this wretched place. The plane was delayed 15 minutes on the tarmac and then 10 more at the gate when no agent was available to operate the entryway. Then, there was an interminable walk through unmarked hallways to an interminable immigration line. There, after being herded to the automated kiosks, I was herded to wait over 40 minutes for an agent who was gleefully asking smug questions of every U.S. citizens in line, spending an average of 5 minutes with each person. Other lines moved more quickly at this point, so this is clearly a particular agent’s power trip. At this point, when I tried to find where to re-check my luggage, an agent rudely asked me for when my connnection was. This was the first time I was asked about my connection time, notwithstanding the “short layover” stickers that had been plastered all over my suitcase. At this point, the rude American Airlines employee told me to go to a different line from the one which I was standing, with now explanation. I assumed, incorrectly, that this was an expedited line, since I still had around 40 minutes to catch my flight. It was not. The door that the rude agent sent me through took me outside of security to the airline agents for rebooking. I learned from another agent that I had been sent there because other agents decided that the remaining 40 minutes was not sufficient for me to make my connection. And, throughout the process, the half-dozen or so staff members that I had the misfortune of interacting with were extraordinarily rude and impassive to the fact that they were part of an inefficient and abusive machine that was making thousands of passengers miserable. Unfortunately, I need to make this same trip for work several times a year. In the future, it will cost me around a hundred dollars to book itineraries on a different airline (probably Delta) in order to avoid this airport. It will be worth every penny.

reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | I have lived and worked in ten countries and flown into and out of dozens of airports. Some are acceptable, others are good, and a few are excellent. After sitting in the Interjet airliner for a full hour after boarding and a flight of about two and a half hours, it took my wife and little granddaughter another three hours to pass through immigration and customs. Such gross inefficiency and total lack of caring for passenger needs is reprehensible. Those responsible for running such an operation should be relieved of their jobs and replaced by competent personnel. Clearly, the travelling public deserves something better than this. Our family will surely not be the only one to avoid using this airport for our future travel needs.

reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | Zero stars if I could rate that low. We sat in the runway for 35-45 minutes after arrival from Barbados - the reasoning because of “other aircraft that needed to taxi”. Go ahead and start the stop watch. We needed to make a connecting flight to Richmond, and we only had an hour to get to our other aircraft. Well 35 minutes wasted sitting in the runway. Thank you either aircraft controllers or American Airlines. Once we were off the plane (another 10 minutes after waiting on the runway ) we made our way through one customs line where literally 500 hundred people were waiting. We waited in customs for another hour - at this point our plane had already started boarding for Richmond. After making it through the customs checks, there were 6 other customs officers sitting around talking and laughing (twiddling their thumbs) Maybe they could have helped open up more lanes in customs? No - poor management. To add on top of all of this, the one line was full of Miami residents that did not need to make a connecting flight. Maybe they could have opened up a different line for solely connecting flights? No - poor management. After customs we then had to pick up our luggage at baggage claim and recheck our luggage! I get this was American Airlines however this was another wasted 30 minutes. After all of this was said and done all but one American line was open so our so called “pre-check passes were useless “After talking with a behind the counter representative from American, they would not reimburse us for a hotel or could they guarantee a seat in the next flight to Richmond. After staying the night in Miami on our expense, we arrived to our gate and American Airlines informed us only seat was available and that my wife could go ahead while I had to wait for another flight 10 hours later. But guess what? This was not a guaranteed seat either. Looks like I’ll be staying in Miami until the I purchase my own set of tickets again. All in all, this was a nightmare that the airport or American Airlines did not want to admit to their poorly planned schematics of arrivals and connecting flights. Hands down the worst flying experience I have ever encountered. - thank you TSA, Customs and American Airlines for ruining my trip. You can check me off your list of being a returning customer. I hope 1000s will read this so they can be forewarned of possible miseries. Something that could have been completely avoided if Miami knew how to run an airport.

author: John Hallam
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | The worst airport I’ve ever had to navigate. We had a 3 hours layover where we were coming in from London. 1. Air traffic control had us circle for 20 minutes. Ok, that happens. 2. Once we landed we were stuck on the tarmac for 40 minutes due to another plane not having docked correctly? and lack of communication regarding which gates the preceding planes were to be at. This doesn’t really happen much, so it was frustrating. 3. We had to go through two different rounds of security screening before having to pick up our checked bags. At the first one, even though we’re had the mobile passport completed, there was no line for mobile passport and with 6 kiosks only 2 were open; one exclusively for crew and global entry with the other for everyone else. 4. We had to then collect our luggage, which took another 30 minutes, to be randomly selected to have them rummage through our things. 5. Once they unfolded everything and left it a mess we were dismissed and sent towards the exit. We then had to recheck our bags at the airline desk which was on a different level and a long way away. Luckily, an airline staff member allowed us to skip the line and simply drop the bags. This was the one person who was helpful; airline staff. 6. Next we had to go through airport security again, however, this time it was the same security you go through if you were just arriving to the airport. Keep in mind we had just gotten off of an airplane here at the airport. Once in the line we got to hurry up and wait while 6 TSA employees condescendingly yelled at everyone. Nothing helpful from them, just threats to slow the line if their power-trip-orders weren’t obeyed. If someone failed to zip up their backpack before sending it through the scanner, instead of asking them to zip it, the person was chastised in front of the crowd. 7. The line of travelers constantly growing while the Walmart approach (having many registers with only one open) was adopted by the TSA staff. One screening conveyor belt was in use while 3 others were closed. With the exception of the lady who was running the conveyor belt, who would not make eye contact with anyone even when asked why my sealed clear bag from the duty free store back in a London was set aside. Nope, my duty free items needed to be taken out and run through another scanner. 8. What was the rest of the TSA staff doing? Literally walking around in circles not know who was supposed to do what. I heard “hey, who is on this one?” And “I though so and so was supposed to be here still” along with other statements that really reassured me our safety was the priority and was being handled by professionals. 9. We were reassured that once through this last “security” check that the gate was literally just up another escalator. Nope. Next we had to jump on yet another shuttle. 10. What’s the best part of this whole experience. The arrival gate (e24) was in the same terminal as the departure gate (e31). All of that fuss was to go through customs. In short, this is the worst airport in the modern world to deal with and I will gladly pay more to fly through another airport in the future so that I can avoid this from happening again.

author: George Rafferty
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | Oh dear no. An awful experience. When you stand in a queue for an hour and 15 minutes with no access to a toilet and nowhere to sit it leaves a bad taste. I have to remind myself as meander like I’m in a queue at Disney that we are meant to be in the most advanced 1st world country on earth. I mean the citizens of this country landed men on the moon 50 years ago and sent satellites to the furthest edges of our solar system yet they can’t efficiently push people through airport arrivals. So after an hour and 15 minutes in a queue we were put into an area of robotic machines by semi robotic staff. One must put the four fingers of one hand on a glass plate on the machine, feed their passport into a slot and look at a light for the machine to take your photograph as if you are facing prison. The machine then spits out a paper ticket with your photo and passport details. In our case although the ticket told us to proceed out one of the semi robotic staff put us to another darn queue. This one took another 45 minutes and when we got to the counter we got to do it all over again. That’s to say, fingerprinted, photographed and passport examined. So what moron thinks it’s a good idea to push hundreds of people to machines only to then put them to human beings to do the exact same thing all over again? Insane duplication and a complete waste of time. I think the Germans call this verschlimmbesserung. So two hours with no access to water, toilet or a seat and to make matters much much worse was that whenever airline crew arrived they got preference over us to go through immigration with no consideration for the fact we’d been standing for hours. When I arrived at the airport I had a lot of sympathy for the folks working here because with the 21st century reincarnation of PT Barnum in the White House they weren’t getting paid but by the time I was standing an hour I felt I wouldn’t pay them either. Barnum may be on capitol hill but arrivals at Miami airport was a horrible circus all of its own.

author: M Barron
reviewBody: Not Verified |  My husband and I flew into the Miami airport on Saturday, December 1 to connect with a cruise that was sailing that day. Our time in the airport was minimal as we were able to quickly locate the transfer service to the port and we were on our way in a short time. On Saturday, December 8 we returned to the Miami airport to await our return flight to Toronto. We arrived at the airport about 9.30 am and our flight was not until 2.00 pm so we had 4.5 hours to spend at the airport and we were not impressed with the experience. Upon getting off the transfer bus, we were directed to an outdoor counter to check our bags. This counter had minimal protection from the weather and we would have been quite uncomfortable if it had been raining or if we had been there mid-day in the hot sun. As others have mentioned, the cost of simple drink and snack options is extremely expensive. Several outlets did not even post prices but just a menu with a list of options. We settled on a coke, coffee and sandwich from the Starbucks outlet situated near gate D32. This location was convenient, well staffed and very clean. The major disappointment concerned the overall unkept state of the airport. There was a lot of garbage blowing around the waiting area where we checked our bags. The washrooms were filthy and the paper towel dispensers were empty. There were plenty of garbage cans but they were overflowing with trash.

author: DeBorah Wright
reviewBody: Not Verified | I am disappointed and disgusted at the level of service at the Miami Airport. We arrived from Costa Rica a family of four, which we had booked our reservations as a family. We were told to stay together through the screening, through customs all the way, which we did. However, the chaos began as soon as we arrived at the Miami airport. My ticket was pre-check as we thought all four would be since they were all booked under my name as the lead person. We were instructed to go to the two different check-points. After being turned around twice, I informed the young lady that we had gone through this twice. If we had to come back, a manager is going to have to get involved. She instructed us to go back to checkpoint three because” the staff member there was new and didn’t know what she was telling us.” We went back, and sure enough, the staff member began to tell us to separate again. I told her what the previous employer had said to us, she pulled up our ticket on her phone and told us to go ahead. I couldn’t believe the level disconnect of communication here in the United States; there is a lot to be learned from Liberia Airport. Courtesy and politeness from the employees for starters. We finally arrived at our gate for departure. As we sat there trying to listen for the changes of gates. The intercom system is not the best; one could barely hear the changes. We saw so many travelers missing their flight and upset, as they should have been. The announcement should have been clear, and anyone on that flight name should have been called before that plane departed. I felt bad for those that were unable to hear the message in the mist of all the chaos. I’m sure that with all the upgrades in technology the intercom system can be much better, employee interaction should be superior. Staff should act as if they want to assist you and not as if they owe you something, remember we are “paying” travelers whether by awards or by credit cards we have paid for service and should be treated with politeness, respect, and clear communication.

reviewBody: Not Verified |  Probably the worst airport experience I've ever had. I was only there for a connection as I was travelling from MBJ- MIA then back to the UK. reviewBody: Not Verified |  I've never been to a more confusing airport in my life. The signs were not straightforward. However, the situation could've been handled much better. The people that worked outside the gate were unhelpful. They pretty much expected everyone to have smart phones and therefore were negligent in giving us, customers, regular updates as to when our flight will arrive. They only updated people who stood waiting in line for 15 minutes, instead of just efficiently announcing it to the general public, not that their updates were helpful to the individuals that stood in line because they kept pushing it to every hour, so it was very hard for customers to plan accordingly. By giving us an incorrect ETA, we were not able to decide whether to rebook to another flight or not. If we had known that the flight was going to be delayed for 5 hours, we would've gotten on a different flight. But the people at the gate kept ensuring us that it would only be an hour delayed, and then another hour if we asked again and again. This misinformation is unacceptable. In addition, the airport was freezing. I had to wait in line for 30 minutes at the Service Center for blankets to be told there were no clean blankets. I would check in with them a few more times and was told there were still no clean blankets available, during this 5 hours waiting period, this huge international airport did not think to provide blankets. So not only was my flight delayed, I caught a fever due to waiting at the cold airport for 5 hours, and had to call out of work the next day.

reviewBody: ❌ Not Verified |  The airport is clean and easy to navigate, you don't have to walk miles between gates. The "fastrack" option or using an automated machine and then passing a receipt to the officer actually takes longer because you have to take 5 minutes to use the machine and then join the back of the queue of people who didn't use it. As always the staff shout at you like they are herding cattle. Departures: Check-in is simple and well signposted, queues are short as there are a lot of desks. Security takes a while, the priority line is not much shorter than the main lines. As with most Americans the staff are very rude and unpleasant. One of them pointed at me and shouted "shoes" whilst another shook his head and announced to the waiting line "we shouldn't have to tell y'all the obvious". It transpired this obnoxious exchange was in fact their attempt to ask me to remove my footwear and place it in the scanning machine, something I would say about 30 percent of airports require, so to me not obvious. But perhaps it was obvious to "y'all".

author: Mark Evans
reviewBody: ❌ Not Verified |  Can MIA achieve any level of competence? I have long boycotted it and advised others to avoid for immigration purposes, and it is not a pleasant airport to negotiate in terms of TSA security. But I did opt to use for transiting between BA6578 (operated by AA) TPA-MIA and BA0208 MIA-LHR on 21 May. On paper, I had two hours for the transit. Flying time between TPA and MIA is just 37 minutes, but weather-related issues made for a TPA departure that was 20 minutes late. On landing at MIA, we then taxied to a halt that lasted 40-45 minutes before a gate was found for us. Pax with tight connections grew anxious as we waited. The AA captain himself lost patience with the false promises of any early move to a gate. A rush to connecting gates and disgustingly dirty bathrooms ensued when we finally deplaned. BA0208 was just starting to board when I finally reached my gate. This was located in a subterranean area of stygian gloom, the waiting customers looking like lost souls, doubtless with their own negative opinions of MIA.

author: E Richards
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | We went on a trip to Orlando and because we couldn't find a fair price for a flight we opted to fly out of Miami. We arrived at midnight so not much to be said about that. Arrival and luggage was ok as was the transportation to the rental cars. On the way back home however, we 'experienced' this airport. The security lines were horrible. Everyone walks around at an immensly slow speed. One person can't be bothered with helping out others. No real info on who needs to go through regular detection gates and who needs to be bodyscanned. Our carry ons were taken apart after being scanned and it took one single security officer about half an hour before he went through our stuff to check. I don't mind that my carry ons need extra screening for whatever reason but please, do it at a decent speed. The security lines were chaotic at best. Once through security I can't say the airport was dirty but the amenities were very limited as was the seating. Once home I also noticed that the TSA cut the security belt around my suitcase open with bolt cutters, even when it had a TSA lock. And they must have had a key since the suitcase as well had a security TSA lock which was correctly opened. I also put a special cloth sleeve around my suitcase to protect it from wear and scratches which I didn't even bother putting back on. When waiting, there is free WiFi but only for 45 minutes. Great when WiFi was a novelty but nowadays simply incomprehensible. Miami Airport is truly on my to-avoid-list of airports now. I guess when visiting Orlando and the airfare is to expensive, you are even better off flying to Atlanta and drive to Orlando.

author: K Burnell
reviewBody: ❎ Not Verified |  Never change here if you can avoid it. Took nearly 2 hours to get through immigration and then we had to run through airport and push to the front of security in order to make our connecting flight (which we had already allowed a 2 hours layover for!). The staff couldn't understand what they were doing, we were queuing into an area where we had to get ESTA receipts and then 45 mins later another load of planes arrive and get guided into a similar area which is inexplicably not being used, with the result that people who had arrived 45 mins after us got through immigration quicker due to poor poor queue management. Cannot understand why those on connecting flights need to do the immigration process, transferring in the UK doesn't require this and it seems really unnecessary when you aren't even leaving the airport.

author: W Davidson
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | From the moment we got off the plane every single employee we encountered in customs and immigration were disrespectful, rude and even down right mean. One gentleman’s job was specifically to tell people which line to filter into and yet he managed to sound extremely annoyed with every human being he came in contact with. The line was painfully long in immigration especially for the non-citizens and when I tried to ask a question to one employee she interrupted me mid question to tell me to keep walking. She treated the next two people who approached her in this same manner. The two women trying to organize the line did it by yelling and talking in bossy, annoyed tones to the hundreds of innocent people who were all just trying to do what they said. When someone made a mistake, heaven forbid if you didn’t exactly understand what “go to the end” means when the room is the size of a football field, then that poor person was berated by the employee who then walked away shaking her head as if every human was an idiot. After our first two negative interactions I started talking to my kids about how we should treat people. They could see how the employees we treating everyone and they could tell that we were just trying to obey whatever “rules” were in place to avoid being singled out. Unfortunately we saw employees act like school yard bullies well over a dozen times and didn’t see one kind exchange in the entire 2 hours that we spent in the Miami airport. Chaotic and horrible.

author: Thomas Ashdown
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | I can say with certainty, even by notoriously bad US airport standards, Miami airport was the worst service I have ever encountered. Signage was useless. Every member of staff I had the displeasure of meeting was hostile to the point of aggression. Information and directions were barked at travelers in an unclear and impatient manner, only for the next member of staff to bark contradicting information leading to the utter bewilderment of passengers. Although there was a large number of staff everything was chaotic and disorganised. A particular low-light of the experience was, when going through security, being told to take my shoes off, (even though I had been told to keep them on moments earlier) and place them directly on the rollers to be scanned. Predictably, seconds later the laces got stuck in the rollers. As I tried to untangle them a member of staff (rather than help) shouted at me repeatedly "Leave it! Leave it! Leave it!". When I explained the laces were tangled he offered no help or apology for his unnecessarily aggressive behavior. But rather stood idly watching the queue grow behind me. I have traveled through 50+ airports, and from the confrontational, incompetent and belligerent service I received, Miami is clearly ranked bottom of the pile.

author: Andrew Smith
reviewBody: ❎ Not Verified |  When I arrived I was excited to see electronic passport controls. However, my passage was not so straightforward because I was not given clearance by the machine. My own fault, I had forgotten to include my middle name on my ESTA application. My friend who regularly transits through Miami says that electronic clearance may or may not help you beat the queues. I eventually reached the head of the queue and was then told to join another queue! I overheard two airport staff mocking a customer who didn't realise that she no longer needed to complete a paper landing form. Well, maybe the customer hasn't flown into the U.S. for a few years? Not a crime is it? Two ladies in the queue behind were appealing to staff because they had 1hr to clear immigration and check in for onward flight but the staff member just sneered at the customer and walked off. Waiting at the yellow line, I could see inside one of the booths where there was a male officer rocking on his chair, staring into space, ignoring the line. Rather strange behaviour. I suppose being an imigration officer must be a difficult job but I have not seen such an unfriendly bunch anywhere and I have been through Boston, New York, Washington, San Fran and Fort Lauderdale. If you are looking for something to eat at Miami airport be prepared for fast food. Next year I hope to avoid Miami altogether and travel via Panama.

author: H Pearson
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | My recent experience at Miami airport when my husband and I were in transit from St Kitts to Toronto was very unpleasant and bordered on being traumatic. We joined the line to have our passports verified on the computers and were given a pass with an X on it. Therefore we had to join another very long line and have our documents verified by an agent. There was a very high volume of passengers and we felt like cattle being herded through, a term which has been used in several other reviews. While waiting, several very burly, tough looking men in uniform passed us by. It was like being in a police state. The agent who received us after a long wait in line was fine, however this was sadly an exception. Many of the airport staff we encountered were surly and rude and could not have cared less about customer service. The fact that they represent their country to a large number of travelers from around the world every day seemed to be irrelevant to them. When we went downstairs to the luggage claim area in order to go to our gate, there were a large number of more tough, burly looking men in uniform watching everyone as they were herded though the area which was intimidating to say the least. When we passed through security, one of the female security staff bawled at me in a loud voice which was totally unnecessary. I have never been spoken to in this manner in my entire life. In addition to the staff, the airport is poorly laid out and signage is confusing. We will avoid travelling via Miami airport in the future.

reviewBody: ❎ Not Verified |  What an outstanding example of American arrogance and rude behaviour this dump is. To the staff: seriously, you're the first Americans that foreign visitors encounter. Why not try to at least make a small effort at being polite and friendly? The impression you give travellers is that America is filled with angry, unpleasant people - you're doing a huge disservice to your country. I witnessed a security guy being incredibly rude to the people in front of me, coming very close to actually yelling at them when all they did was turn right out of a doorway instead of left (and no signage to say otherwise). If you don't like people and have zero tolerance for other humans then stay away from a customer-facing job. Almost every staff member was rude, impatient and abrasive, all of them shouting and bullying the airport visitors. There were a few exceptions who stood out. Even though he probably sees a million people in a week, he was polite and told us to have a nice day and it made all the difference. Also, the passport guy we had was professional and friendly. It put me off ever going near America again, for a holiday or to pass through.

reviewBody: ❎ Not Verified |  An ok airport but a shocking entrance to the US. This airport has more staff than customers, it’s amazing how many people are employed here. There are 2 huge English grammar mistakes on this, really that’s your first impression? Then there is an announcement on level 3 about “moving walks” they are called escalators in every country! Why make up child like words? 99% of the staff here are Spanish speaking which I like, but I could see how someone without Spanish may struggle. Doesn’t help I counted 3 different dialects/versions of Spanish translated on signs, confusing! Once they work out which way to face on the moving walk, seriously? Forget immigration checks, should of had IQ checks.

author: N Bayker
reviewBody: ❎ Not Verified |  I'm not at all surprised to read other reviews about rude staff, bad experiences and passengers being treated like prisoners or cattle at Miami airport. Chaos reigns, and is presided over by employees who make it blatantly obvious that they hate their jobs. When we transited via Miami in January and February 2018, a handful of the staff really stood out for their competence and pleasant attitude, but they were the exception, the other 90% were miserable, surly, disinterested and in some cases quite unbelievably rude. Procedures and systems seem ridiculously slow and inefficient, and passengers have to stand in long queues multiple times as they are inhumanely processed. The layout of the airport doesn't help, signage is poor and in any case you're directed to ignore the few potentially useful signs by stressed employees whose job is apparently to stand underneath them yelling the same thing at people all day long. No wonder they're grumpy. Overall, not a positive experience at all. Anyone who arrives here is made to feel very unwelcome indeed. Come on, Miami, there has to be a better way - just look at almost any other airport.

reviewBody: ❎ Not Verified |  Having endured lengthy immigration delays at this and other US airports I got trusted traveller status. reviewBody:
❎ Not Verified |  
Arrived from Frankfurt at 2.40 pm after flying business class. Got to the customs and noticed ridiculosly long lines. I looked for some type of separation by class or nationality and nothing, everybody was lumped together. There were at least 500 people in that large room, all lined up line cattle to the slaughter. Really, don’t American citizens deserve an easier entry into their own country? After waiting patiently in line for 3/4 hr, got to a passport machine where my passport was read and got a receipt with an X on it, I guess they could not believe I had nothing to declare, hence I was placed into another line where a real agent would re review my entry. Waited another 15 minutes and while waiting I noticed that most agent run kiosks were assigned to X passengers. Well if this the case, why bother with the machines, they cost money and they are useless. Finally, the agent called me and he seemed very nice, talkative and accomodating. He was sure to ask me if I had anything to declare which I responded: ‘maybe a cold’. Overall uneventful but why the bureacracy, can we not do better? One thing is for sure, if I can skip Miami airport, I will be more than happy to do so. I forgot to mention the hellishly long security lines when I left 1 week prior, what a total joke.

author: D Cooper
reviewBody: ✅ Trip Verified | I was surprised at how disorganized the Airport was. The advertised free wifi was not available, the security crew was extremely rude literally hearding the passenngers thru the checks calling out things like “pay attention”, “stay focused” etc. It reminded me very much of my military drill. I have not experienced such behavior at any other US airport where TSA is usually very efficient but polite enough at the same time to make passengers comfortable. While waithing at the Business line for the security check at least three wide-body aircraft crews (= min 75 to 80 crew) were bypassed and led thru the business checks (on most other airports I have seen dedicated crew security lanes). When it was finally my turn I was redirected to the economy lane and had to wait again. At the x-ray machine there were no bins and when I dared to point this out to the TSA staffI was rebuked with “didn't you hear me!? I already called this out twice! bins are on their way”. The entire process took over 45 minutes. After the security check, the food court service staff was pleasant but the janitors and cleaning crew were very unattentive with litter piling up on many tables. Once they did come around they cleared tables even while patrons were still eating their food. Tables were not wiped and felt very sticky obviously not having been cleaned for some time. It seems to me that there is a serious motivational problem with a large number of employees at MIA that I have not witnessed on the many other US airports that I arrive to or leave from.

reviewBody: ❎ Unverified |  One would think that walking from gate D8 to D36 would not be that far. author: Richard Hodges
reviewBody: ❎ Unverified |  Miami - London Heathrow, Thursday 19 October: Despite the many bad reviews this airport, in our experience, has improved greatly since the car rental centre was moved virtually on site with a short connecting shuttle train service. No more catching those awful shuttle busses with all your luggage. Also the electronic immigration machines have sped up the previously awful queueing time upon arrival. This time we flew back to the UK with Virgin Atlantic: driving in with the aid of SatNav and the very few road signs we got to the car rental hub without any issues. Put the luggage into a storage facility until we could check in with Virgin - we were a bit early so first in the queue - and got through security after about 1/2 hour. Travelling Upper Class so found the Lounge and did not bother with the many, many fast food outlets, sports bars or coffee places. The big downside of Miami Airport has always been the crowded concourses and very poor signage - only seems marginally better now. The WiFi was also slow. But all things considered the airport is better than it used to be. Tip: If you don't have access to a lounge or have a few hours to kill there is an open air cafe/bar on the top floor of the Hotel that we used to go to. It also connects to an indoor bar with sports screens and air - con. I believe you can pay to use the Health Club and use the pool as well, and the view over the runways is spectacular.

reviewBody: ✅ Verified Review |  Miami is a very large and old airport. This place looks so dingy and old, it was like stepping back in time! It consisted of Pizza Hut, a small beer place, and two freestanding snack stands. That was it. When I got out to the actual gate, there was nothing. There were a few "stores" but they weren't open and I don't know if they are even functional. It was for a 5.30pm flight which ended up being delayed. There were bathrooms, and seating, but nothing else. Everything was closed up. There were 4 different gates where I was. There was a business class lounge not too far for Iberia business passengers, or American Airlines. At this area they did have a duty free shop which was small. The waiting area was fairly clean and the seats were comfortable enough. You have 30 minutes of free wifi after that you have to pay for it. I was early for my flight so the line to go through security and waiting to check in were not long. I had to take a short train to get out to the gates. This airport is serious need of an overhaul. It looks like the 1960's. The buses are in one area on the lower level. Depends on the airline you fly which terminal you are out of.

reviewBody: ✅ Verified Review |  I transited MIA on my way to St Maarten and arrived and departed on my way back to London. My first arrival was at 4pm from an international flight. From deplaning to jumping into a taxi took us about 30 minutes.

reviewBody: Got a great deal from BA saving over £500 for three people so decided to fly into Miami. Last time we did this was in 2006 and it wasn't a great experience with a lot of building work, long immigration queues, offsite car hire, etc. So I was extremely apprehensive. What a difference 10 years makes. We were off of the plane and into a very small queue for the automated machines (not sure what they are called) but there was at least 20 of them so the queue moved quickly, five minutes at most. Once that was done (another five minutes) we were directed to the manual booths because our daughter had just changed her passport. There was no queue whatsoever. Another five minutes of her having her fingerprints done and photo taken and we were off to baggage collection where we waited for 30 minutes for our bags to arrive. A ten minute walk to the train / shuttle which takes you to the car hire / transportation hub where again there were very short lines. I think two people were in front of us. My guess is we were off the plane, through immigration and in the parking garage in just over an hour tops. Amazing. Having read about Orlando I have to say that I think I'd prefer to do this again and then spend four hours driving up than be stuck for hours at MCO being shouted at. The only reason I'm not giving this 10/10 is because there is another airport in Florida that gets you through even quicker and I'm worried that everyone is going to figure it out and fly there instead. You don't need to be a brain surgeon to know which one I'm talking about.

reviewBody: Arrived a tad more than 3 hours before a flight to Montreal. Checked in online the night before. Did the rest on the American Airlines machines. My baggage tag printed blank. author: D Mackenzie
reviewBody: What an experience. I can honestly say having travelled around Europe, Asia, Africa and the US, Miami has to be one of the worst airports I've ever encountered. The immigration process is laughable, poor signage, really unhelpful staff, automated ESTA machines, queues upon queues. We were queueing for around 3 hours (and was informed this was a quiet period) just to get a customs and immigration officer who could have hardly cared less. Not one question,  just more photos. All this time your baggage has been unloaded from the conveyor belt and left lying around 'unattended' which surely goes against the regular tannoys you hear at every airport but obviously not applicable to Miami. After that came the trek for the car rental. Don't be fooled by the $5 dollar baggage cart as that will only get you a short bit of the way before you're obliged to ditch it and then haul all your belongings the rest of the way to the rental terminal which is conviently located as far away as humanly possible without leaving the airport zip code. Again met by people who obviously don't wish to be there. 2 weeks later and departure was no better. The only saving grace was car rental returns was quick and painless but again hauling your luggage back through to departures where you're again met with partially automated check in, queues and unhelpful staff. All in all, a miserable experience from start to finish. I understand now why flights are cheaper to Miami than Orlando. If at all possible avoid this airport and save yourself an awful lot of grief.

reviewBody: Changing flights from an International flight to another international in the US seems to have become a nightmare. author: Giorgio Gianesini
reviewBody: We had a stopover in Miami during our flight from Mexico Cancun to Madrid. Having read all the nightmare stories for immigration, losing flights and baggage re-checking, I was prepared for the worst, but we were in reality so lucky and suprised that I want to share it also our experience because it is not always so negative. First, flying AA/Iberia the bags had an "ITI orange tag" and so they were transferred from the AA flight to Iberia flight. As said on the Miami airport website this is depending on airlines and destinations, but it's not true that you have always to pick up your bags during a transit. Secondly, in the period between 7.30pm/8pm few flights were landing from "non US airports", so we arrived at APC kiosks with many of them free, so in 10 minutes we were queuing to have the stamp from the officer. Then, it starts the usual "not so good" part because: Signs are not ok when you leave immigration, because in reality following signs you would probably come to leave the airport since there are arrows for connecting flights moving you outside the terminal when in reality you have to follow the AA connecting flights indications (despite our flight was Iberia for the next leg). Metal detectors/body scanner for the connecting flights are few so you need at least to add 20/30 minutes in your calculation (and again the airport was quite empty at that time). So, in general our experience has been positive overall, because 45 minutes from leaving a first flight to the departure gates again seems a very good "score", in general however I also understand the other reviews because during busy times/hours especially the connecting part/metal detectors seems not adequate to manage thousands of people.

author: M Rosales
reviewBody: Miami International by far was the worse experience I have had. I arrived internationally with my sister and had a 3 hour layover. Upon arriving we immediately found ourselves waiting in an endless line for US Citizens that got us to kiosks. Then we proceeded to another endless line to another group of kiosks for customs that were for re entry. There were no instructions just lines, no assistance at the kiosks as well. It was a free for all. After we got our picture taken by the machine, we then waited in line to get into another line to wait to go through customs with a live person. After he went through our kiosk sheets and declaration we went through some doors and had to retrieve our luggage. I have never had to do this before and found it ridiculous. The baggage area was all spread out, there were no clear indicators of what flights they came from and many luggage were taken off the belt and scattered in clusters. It took a while to even find my bag which had my lost and found tag missing. Once we found our bags in the mess they call baggage claim, we stood in another enormous line to go through another live person. By then I had less than an hour left until my connecting flight took off. We finally got through and the person who told us how easy it would be was lying. No one was at the end to take our bags and direct us to the next flight. I was separated from my sister and put in a rescheduled flights line. A person who worked there saw me asked where I was going and took me out of line. I was shoved out of the customs/international area to the front of the airport with my bags. A person out there checked in my bag for me and told me to run with less than 30 min before my flight took off. I was told to run to go through screening again. Then had to cut in line because my flight was to depart in less than 15 min. Once I went through, my departing gate was at the other end of the building. No one was willing to give me a ride on the carts when I asked either. So my pregnant self, had to run/walk to the other end. I was out of breath and stressed when I arrived at my gate. Everyone had boarded and I made it with minutes to spare. The disorganization, lack of customer service and re entry procedures are seriously flawed. I had a terrible experience here.

author: Susan Marshall
reviewBody: I've now had 2 horrendous experiences at Miami. The first was several years ago when much of the airport was under construction. However, most recently there was no construction in sight. We stood in line for 30-40 minutes to use the "automated passport control" machines. Then we stood in an even longer line to actually go through immigration stations with live attendants that seemed to look and function exactly like every immigration station I've ever gone through in the US. I saw absolutely no benefit to the APC function. To make it even worse - there were 2 stations for the 75 percent of incoming passengers who were US citizens. However if you were a foreign national or had got an X on your receipt from the wonderful machines, there were over a dozen stations for you and you were probably sipping a mojito in your hotel while the US citizens were still waiting in line. 1 hour 40 minutes from landing to exiting customs. In the past year I've been in 30 countries and 70+ airports including Beijing, Ho Chi Minh, Hanoi, Delhi and Miami was the worst for immigration. A work colleague said he'd had exactly the same experience - his foreign-born mother got an X and was through immigration many times faster than he was. I will avoid Miami as an entry point to the US in the future.

author: Marie Chapman
reviewBody: The worst airport I have ever arrived at. An ESTA queue formed so I put myself into that queue with everyone else, one member of staff shouting at anyone with a visa to join him, no one did so after an hour I finally made it to what I thought was customs, but a machine, a free for all. No staff and everyone was playing with a machine that they didn't know how to use, after doing everthing it asked me a big cross through my face. Again no staff. Eventually I walked through to get my case, that was the easy part, laid on the ground in the middle of baggage collection. 3 and a half hours in total to leave that building - never again.

author: Richard Hodges
reviewBody: Travelled on BA207 landing in Miami 1st November. We have travelled through Miami many times in the past and I have been scathing in previous reviews - TSA checks, immigration and car rental issues have been horrendous. However, to be fair to the airport, things have been changing for the better. Crucially the car rentals have been centralised so that just a short shuttle train journey is required as the cars are now on site. A huge improvement. And now we have the APC (Automatic Passport Control) machines which, frankly, are amazing for those of us with ESTA waivers. We were through immigration, customs, and baggage retrieval within 45 minutes - and onto the interstate within 75 minutes, arriving at Naples on the Gulf Coast before sunset! One can only hope that all American ports of entry introduce the APC system (please Newark, Washington Dulles, Chicago etc). The one remaining bad thing is the signage - it is still pretty awful for tourists and needs to be worked on. We travelled back from Tampa so cannot comment on what Miami is like inbound.

author: Peter Kay
reviewBody: Arrival at airport a nightmare, long walks and even longer queues. Visitors arriving with ESTA's need to use electronic terminals and input their own data. All well and good if you can get to one in the first place when there are many flights arriving at the same time. When you do eventually get to a terminal it struggles to take your finger print (unless you can disconnect your fingers from your hand) and ultimately issues you with a reject slip which you then have to present to the immigration officer by joining the another queue (the one you tried to join in the first place). I estimate that 90% of visitors using the electronic terminals received rejection slips and then had to re queue. The whole experience has put me off using Miami airport again as it took over two hours to clear immigration. This is unfortunate as I have seen using this airport for over twenty years when visiting Naples.

author: E. Middleton
reviewBody: What a nightmare this airport is. Super expensive food. $37 for a burger, fries, a bourbon and soda and mandatory 18% tip at the pub-like restaurant in Concourse D. Another "meal" (dry turkey sandwich and beverage for $18 at Concourse F). Customers there were pushy and rude. No tables available. No one takes the meal vouchers issued by American Airlines. Why do they issue these worthless pieces of paper? American Airlines, airport, TSA, ICE, restaurant staff? Rude. Snippy. Unhelpful. Often incompetent. Never a smile. Never a please or thank you or I'm sorry. Most try and ignore you, by avoiding eye contact. I lived in NYC for 25 years and JFK and LGA are bastions of kindness and grace compared to this pit of bad manners. Most AA announcements at the gate in Spanish, and informal Spanish at that. When English is used, the announcements are often shorter with less information. Iberia does a better job with the English. Concourse F looks like something out of 1985. Industrial carpet. Worn chairs. Crowded, with many sitting on the floor. No TSA pre-check and no shopping. Just a few lame fast food joints, and an overpriced bar. In fairness, Concourse D, the American Airlines zone, is quite nice, modern, with a coral reef-themed terrazzo floor, though not much open after 9 PM. F and D are not connected, so you have to go through security twice to get to D (and the AA lounge) and back. The check-in areas for many of the non-U.S. airlines, e.g. Iberia, have also seen better days. Crowded, noisy, glaring fluorescent lighting, claustrophobic. Again, 1980s ambiance. No functioning Wi-Fi. They promise 30 minutes free, but I sure didn't get it. A 10-minute line for the ICE passport reading machines on entry to the U.S. A number were broken. Imagine: a line for a machine!! And then another line to turn in the paper produced by the machine. Slow baggage claim. About 45 minutes after the door opened, luggage arrived. Taxi pick up area is choked with diesel exhaust fumes.

author: Tonya Butts
reviewBody: I don't know what went on at Miami Airport the other night. But I travel once a year for a vacation and I have never had an experience like this. You could tell the employees knew things were going wrong. The lines from the baggage pick up and recheck were crazy, undefined with no ropes. They wound back on themselves and around you couldn't find the end of the line, no one knew what was going on. People were cutting in line, people were angry and anxious because they knew they were going to miss flights. It was like they were unprepared by the influx an sheer volume of people. Employees were trying to make up for what they knew was becoming a bad situation by hustling people through safety points opening up lines sideways shoving people up front, nobody knew what was going on. We were told don't even take your shoes off just get your stuff on the x-ray machine. Quickly, quickly. I paid $1400 in air tickets, I deserve to be treated with a certain level of respect and to feel safe. There were at least three flights canceled by my terminal alone. I believe that it was because the flights weren't full due to the number of persons stuck somewhere in that airport and couldn't make it to their flights. In general it was a horrible experience and I'm pretty sure that's a General consensus of all of us who were there. Maybe that's not what it's like everyday, but I'm not anxious to go back to find out. That was just terrible.

author: Diana Pincott
reviewBody: This is the worst airport I've experienced as a business traveller. Avoid it at all costs. Unclear signage for ESTA waiver program, coupled with inaccurate advice by officials on where to queue should you arrive with an ESTA. Immigration queue was endless, sped up slightly when I left the visitor queue, went to the automated machines for a receipt and joined a shorter queue. Immigration took two hours and I was only transiting. Signage for transit passengers after customs was unclear. Officials present were uninterested in dealing with passengers enquiry and provided curt answers in the most grumpy way. The queues at the TSA security check were also long, with an official standing at the entrance to the queue proclaiming to passengers that any duty free alcohol purchase should be in sealed bags. It was like a pantomime. I had a three-hour layover and just about made it to the D gates on the sky train for my connecting flight to Central America. On my return trip on a Sunday afternoon, the immigration queue was shorter since I went straight to the automated machines for a receipt. The TSA security check area was even more chaotic, this time with the addition of body scanning and body search. Officials seemed more interested in talking to each other rather than doing their job. The airport management need to rethink the signage and the queue management system and consider some customer service training for their staff.

author: E Pritchard
reviewBody: Going through customs was a nightmare, while there were several extra machines that could've been opened that officers were too busy taking photos or talking. I watched and overheard another customer finally flag down an officer, concerned they were going to miss their next flight putting them off schedule for the flight following, to which the officer rudely told the customer they would just have to be patient and that the airport was doing all they could to expedite the process. Getting luggage when going through customs is a nightmare and I now chose to only bring a carry on, no matter how much it weighs. I travel with an ESA to which an officer pushed aside with her foot and who's leash I was forced to remove by another officer before going through metal detector meaning I had to go through the metal detector, grab my bag and belongings from the conveyor belt while bent over holding my ESA's harness. Once out of customs I checked the boards to confirm the gate on my boarding pass was still correct, to which the boards confirmed it was. Not having a lot of extra time after my customs experience, I headed straight to the gate and sat to wait. However, as the time grew closer to boarding I noticed there were not a lot of passengers even though the board above the counter said my flight. When I asked at the counter I was informed that the gate had been changed and they hadn't gotten around to changing it, and that I should've been better prepared and downloaded the airport app since the boards couldn't be trusted. After receiving a lecture from the desk clerk he then gave me directions to the gate and told me he would call ahead to tell them I was coming as fast as possible. Following his directions, I discovered he had sent me to the wrong terminal, so I then reboard the tram and raced to the gate at which there was no one managing the counter and I watched my plane's doors close and take off 5 minuets early. Since this was the last flight to my final location I had to spend the night in Miami and was rebooked on the earliest flight out the next morning. When I arrived at the airport the next morning around 5 am, 2.5 hours before my flight, I found 1 security line open with people backed up to the doors that lead to the outside. Once I finally got to the front of the line I had a security officer refuse to allow my ESA to pass until I fully removed his harness, make him sit and wait while I passed through the metal detector. Once finally through they changed my gate twice, neither of which were on the boards. Avoid MIA if possible.

author: Jacqui Sclanders
reviewBody: Travelled with my family from Miami on 31 July to Heathrow. Whilst gathered in concourse F there was a chaotic element to food service and rudeness too. Not a great start for our first visit to this airport. It got worse. The ladies' restroom in this concourse was in a deplorable state, dirty and used paper hand towels strewn on the floor, an abandoned cleaner's cart, no paper roll in the individual cubicles leading to disgust and abandonment from many ladies. What a way to showcase your airport Miami. I did a twitter note about this and received a reply that the situation would be dealt with. Hopefully subsequent passengers benefitted but there seemed to be no management presence or care on the floor and that is a shameful state of affairs. I would not visit this airport again by choice and would choose to travel to another airport to avoid it. What a shambles.

author: Gilbert Schwartz
reviewBody: I arrived at MIA North Terminal on AA39 on August 1 2015 at approximately 9.00 pm. The people mover car used for transiting from the plane to the customs area had no functioning air conditioning. None of the escalators down to the customs arena were functioning. Although I participate in the “Global Entry” program, the receipt was marked “X” which required me to stand in line for an officer’s review. The agent on duty left his post to explain to others in line what would be permitted and not permitted through this entry point. This caused further unnecessary delay. There was clearly poor judgment in allocation of customs personnel duties. There was an inordinately long wait for my luggage to arrive at the carrousel. After retrieving my luggage there was an extremely long line filing through the maze to arrive at the exit. I presented my “X” entry pass and passport, I found the officer to be rude in his tone and very unwelcoming. Overall, this experience at MIA was extremely unpleasant.

reviewBody: The staff is rude and has a terrible attitude. Going through customs, my boyfriend and I asked an employee about the permanent resident line, she simply yelled at us to stay in line. I'm never gonna take a flight out of that airport again, nor recommend it to anybody.

author: C M Lilley
reviewBody: Never again. After a delayed American Airways flight we were concerned that our planned 6.5 hour transit time had reduced to 3 hours. The queues through passport control were very long, our baggage took an age to appear, baggage trolley cost an outrageous $5, then there was the astonishingly long line to get through customs control. Whenever we asked if, as transit passengers, we really needed to go through this channel we were shouted at to "Get in Line". Finding our way to the check in for our onward flight was confusing and extremely frustrating. Eventually, a very kindly security guard recognised our distress and directed us to our destination. By this time we were worried that we would miss our flight as we had passed the "gate closed" deadline. Thankfully we made it, just. As a couple well over 70, one of us having an obvious medical problem (broken shoulder) we would never transit Miami again. On our arrival at Heathrow we found our luggage had stayed in Miami - both cases having been opened and inspected by security.
